page.lettertext:
fol.269r
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
:
Belgia 1590 27 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. heer is now in
Delft
one
Docto
r
Josepho
an Italian phisitian not unknowen to
yo
r
L. as I do p
r
sume, because hee hath bin physitian to
the
Pr. of Orenge
, and hath made some abode, about
the court in
England
. Lieng sick in his bedd, he was
visited by an old friend of his one
Reynold Peeterson
a shipper of
Hoorn
, who came out of
Spaine
but
this p
nt
daie, by whome hee was adv
r
tized of a secret
practize against her
Ma
ties
son, wh
r
uppon hee sent
the partie to the
Hage
, a man as hee saith & should
seem by his cariage, well
suaded in religion & of
a good discretion whom I &
M
r
Gilpin
examined
alone, & this hee declared. that the 6 of May
last hee went from
Lisbone
in a ship of
Embden
& after his arrivall hee came to
Madril
the
8 of June where he sojourned till the 19
th
of
July, making meanes, to the
King
for the release of
certaine shippes. the King being then in a c
r
taine
cloister, 7 miles distant from Madril, during
his staie in that place hee had often conference
w
t
a very spetiall friend & his cousen, one
Nicolas Messe
a shipper of Embden, whom hee mett
w
th
all there sewing to be satisfied for the losse of
a great ship that perished in the Armado. By reason
of his long sute & continewance in the Court, the
said Nicolas Messe had gotten some acquaintance
& accesse unto
sons of principall quality, amonge
whom hee had learned w
ch
hee im
ted in secret
to this Reynold Peeterson that one
Pedro Aster
of
Arragon
, a Spaniard borne and a notorious
malefactor for divers murders & other villanies was
gon of purpose into England to execute some mischief
upon her Ma
ties
son, w
ch
hee determined at two
severall times to have attempted, but hee wanted
likely meanes, w
ch
yet hee attended, to scape
upon yt. This Pedro of Arragon to
cure himself
credyt, will minister all occasions to enveigh
against the King, & to make yt seem to her Ma
ty
that hee would enterprise any thing to doe him some
annoyance
fol.269v
Belgia: 1590: Au
g
:
The names of those
sons, by whom the foresaid
ty
had Received this intelligence were unknowen unto him
for that hee enquired not curiously after all that I
demaunded, But hee hath
mised that as soone as
his Cousen shall retourne out of Spaine, w
ch
hee
think
willbee w
th
in this moneth, whatsoever hee hath
heard hee shall descover unto mee & for more
assurance of his speedy coming, yf her Ma
ty
shall
require yt hee will call him home p
ntl
y, & send
him into England, Howbeyt hee think
that if Pedr
[o]
be declaimed & put to torture, theie shall need no oth
r
proofe of his wicked intention. Moreov
r
this Reinold
Peeterson signifyeth that one
Henry van de Boes
a
shipper of
Middlebourgh
told him in secret Communicatio
[n]
that a chief servant of
Don
Antonio
w
ch
was then in
Spaine & at
e Court was the greatest instrum
t
for
the carriage of letters & messages, between this
Pedro of Arragon & his coorespondent
in Spaine
For any matters besides hee declareth onely this
that he sawe at the Groine to the nomb
r
of
100 shippes of all sort
& theie had hard yt
spoken that there was at hand in those quarters
4000 souldiers, & 4000 more in Biscay likewise
12 oth
r
ships of 1200 & 1400 tonnes lowe built, of
w
ch
6 were at
Bilbo
, and 6 at
S
t
Anderes
, & all
in a readines in all places to set p
nt
ly forward
hee thought not w
th
standing because the time was
much delayed, that they exspected the issue of so
[me]
spetiall practise. And this I thought w
th
all dili
[gence]
to certify yo
r
L. & too bessech yo
u
that all tho this
bearer were oth
r
wise minded to goe into England, because
at my entreaty hee de
teth soddainely, & hath
mised
to bee w
th
yo
u
w
th
all possible speed, hee may bee
some what considered for his paines & charges,
& thus
I take my humble leave. Au
g
27 A
o
1590.
